purple_launch.csv.flight_description: The servo died right before the launch, so this was just a data collection flight. It was with the first iteration of the Airbrakes code, so it doesn't have all of the fields we normally log. Our rotation data is not accurate, so we cannot get a good velocity estimate for most of the flight.

shake_n_bake.csv.flight_description: First flight of AirbrakesV2. Airbrakes were coded to deploy automatically after roughly 1 second in CoastState. However they did not deploy due a mechanical issue. LandedState was triggered too early and did not capture touchdown. Generated Data packets were added to file to mimmick a touchdown. We missed logging some quaternions because they were reported invalid by the IMU, and were added in during post-processing later.

genesis_launch_1.csv.flight_description: First flight of apogee prediction code. Apogee prediction worked well. This was our first attempt of a control launch. We tried to have it extend its airbrakes for most of coast and then retract them, but later analysis proved that airbrakes didn't deploy during coast. See https://github.com/NCSU-High-Powered-Rocketry-Club/AirbrakesV2/issues/91 for more details.

genesis_launch_2.csv.flight_description: Second flight of apogee prediction code. Airbrakes were set to deploy once at around the start of CoastState and were commanded to never retract. The fins were extended upon recovery of the rocket. This was very similar to first flight and airbrakes failed to deploy at the intended time. See https://github.com/NCSU-High-Powered-Rocketry-Club/AirbrakesV2/issues/91 for more details.

legacy_launch_1.csv.flight_description: First flight with encoder and camera. Very high uncertainity in quaternions from the IMU. The timestamp also jumped a bit, and a few seconds of data was missing and/or inconsistent. Encoder and video data did show airbrakes physically deploying though, but during free fall. This launch told us that there is a massive latency in sending packets to the main process.

flight_data.landed_coordinates_precision: unknown, should be close to exact

legacy_launch_2.csv.flight_description: Complete waste of a flight since the velocity was negative at standby state due to excessive gyro drift. No data past standby state. The camera fell through the mount, so no footage would've been recorded anyway.

flight_data.landed_coordinates_precision: almost exact - forgot to measure - no wind drift of AVAB

pelicanator_launch_1.csv.flight_description: First flight of the Pelicanator. This was the first flight with the Raspberry Pi 5, and the first flight in which airbrakes 100% worked. However the flight itself was a failed VDF launch, crash landing and thus the data was cutoff before landing, resulting in a loss of ~22 seconds of flight data. The camera was in the payload for this flight, but that didn't work, so there's no footage of it deploying.

flight_data.landed_coordinates_precision: approximate - wind dragged it by a lot after landing

pelicanator_launch_2.csv.flight_description: Second flight of the Pelicanator. Airbrakes didn't deploy because it was very windy and we significantly undershot our apogee. No other problems were there with airbrakes for this flight.

flight_data.landed_coordinates_precision: approximate - wind dragged it by a lot after landing

pelicanator_launch_3.csv.flight_description: Final flight before Huntsville. For this flight, the servo died right before launch, requiring a rewrite of the servo logic to work with only one servo. We had on board footage from the payload for the first time, which showed airbrakes deploying correctly in coast. However they were unable to retract mechanically. The rocket was also dragged through the mud by the wind for a long time after landing, which broke the fins, and also corrupting the SD card, and thus we don't have data for this flight. The final coordinates from where the rocket was recovered was 35.18224,-76.83000

flight_data.landed_coordinates_precision: approximate - recovery photos show about 20-30m dirt trail

pelicanator_launch_4.csv.flight_description: This was the 2024-2025 Huntsville flight. The flight was relatively normal with except for some weather cocking, though this wasn't too crazy. The motor took a while to fully ignite and build up pressure, so a lot of it was spewed out before fulling launching which resulted in a lower apogee. For this flight, predicted apogee was significantly lower than actual apogee, likely due to converging too soon. The camera worked on the payload, and air brakes did not deploy. LandedState was triggered about ~5 seconds too late, because there was not a large enough acceleration spike, probably due to a higher horizontal velocity rather than vertical.

lil_frank.csv.flight_description: Interest Launch 2025. This flight had a airbrakes redesign to increase surface area. This launch was scrubbed because the secondary drogue system failed to arm, and we couldn't get it working in time.
